segments.text: So it was kind of a shock to leave Vietnam where we were sitting and waiting on aircraft to pick us up that we didn't know whether or not it was going to get off the ground or not and hoping that it didn't get blowed away before we got out of the country.
all of a sudden in 16 hours you're back in civilization.
So it was a quick change that was a culture shock to you.
The culture was kind of quite different in Vietnam.
Yeah, quite different.
It was a pretty filthy place.
Lots of rats, lots of black plague, lots of infection, lots of
You know, wounds didn't heal good there because of the infection in the field.
People were morally, you know, Vietnamese people didn't have a whole lot to live for, the majority, unless you were upper class, you know.
The French.
Yeah.
And they, you know, women used the bathroom on the roads, you know, in front of everybody, you know.
Men did too.
It didn't make any difference.
You know, so there, it was kind of, culture was kind of bad.
So, we had mama sons, took care of our stuff, you know, washed our clothes.
Of course, they washed our clothes with rice soap and beat them with rocks so they didn't last a long time, you know.
And, uh,
But we paid them $5 a month.
And they'd polish our boots and wash our clothes and anything we needed to cook, whatever, for $5.
So later on, after you'd been there a while and you were able to get some food, they cooked it for you.
Yeah, well, they'd cook theirs if you could eat it.
Oh, I see.
They'd cook their monkey.
Back to the monkeys, right?
Well, you know, I never saw the monosons eating meat.
They ate mostly plants of some kind.
I don't know.
I guess something like spinach on that order, greens of some kind.
Stonk.
Oh, it wasn't spinach then.
No, probably not.
Did you go into Saigon?
Yeah.
What was it like?
Saigon was filthy, just like I just described.
Really?
Yeah.
Well, that was kind of a modern city.
It was supposed to be the Paris of the Orient.
That's what I thought.
That's why I heard that.
But it wasn't.
It was filthy.
Well, have you ever heard about Paris?
Yeah.
Paris is not your cleanest thing either.
It's pretty filthy in Paris.
Saigon.
The problem in Saigon, most guys would tell you that, a lot of guys would tell you that they'd rather be in the jungle where you shot whoever came out
than to be in Saigon where you got shot because you didn't know.
Lots of people got killed in Saigon, terrorists killing people every day, gobs of them.
I'll tell you, I believe the 716th MPs in Saigon was involved in as much or more combat than anybody in Vietnam.
Their headquarters got hit every day by mortar rounds.
From VC.
Yeah, their living quarters.
every day.
Did they have any Air Force security placement there?
Oh, yeah.
Lots.
I was going to ask you a while ago approximately how many you had towed.
We had about a thousand.
You had a thousand that drove at Gardner Bay?
Yeah.
We had security patrols, then we had machine gun emplacements, and then we had towers.
And we pulled those ditties, you know, we shared those ditties, and we'd
We would police until 11 o'clock curfew, and then at 11 o'clock we'd go into machine gun bunkers and guard the perimeter.
Sometimes you'd be in a machine gun jeep, patrolling mobile.
We traded 10 cots one time for an APC, an armored personnel carrier, and it had two 30-caliber machine guns on it.
And it was pretty wild.
Nobody knew how to operate the machine guns because it was remote control.
We drove it around for a while.
Did it scare the Vietnamese?
Oh, yeah, they liked it.
They liked that thing.
But that's what you did.
Well, I think it's about time we wound this up.
But could you...
First of all, but before we do, I'd like to know how you felt after you came back to the United States.
Very, very bitter.
And hearing, but how did you feel when you heard the news and you knew it was wrong?
Is that what made you so bitter?
What was wrong?

When you knew they were lying to the American people, the politicians were lying to the American people about what was going on, and you couldn't say anything about it, you couldn't do anything about it?
I don't know how I felt.
You said you were bitter.
I was bitter because of the way the American people did the veterans while they were overseas.
Up until just a few years ago, I was very, very bitter.
I still feel that the American people killed as many GIs in Vietnam as the enemy did.
I feel like that they were responsible for a lot of the
the deaths, the American deaths in Vietnam.
Are you aware that there's only about two paragraphs in the history books nowadays concerning the Vietnam War and some that's not even in there?
I guess probably because it's such an embarrassment.
Do you think that even in spite of whether it's the fact that it's an embarrassment that the American children should study about it?
Sure, I think they should.
I think they should know the truth about it.
I think it's wrong for them to
to get away with a bunch of lies that shields a lot of that stuff.
No one will ever convince me that the American position, the majority, or I feel like the majority, the feelings of the soldier in Vietnam did not kill a lot, a lot of soldiers, American soldiers.
and caused their death in Vietnam.
You know, there was a lot of anti-war movements going on in the United States.
Were you aware that this was just a small minority of the student population, or even the population of the United States?
No.
We were never told.
We always heard about all the demonstrations.
We were never told about anything good.
Well, they were a very small minority.
The good or the bad?
The people who were demonstrators, the anti-war demonstrators, were a very small minority of the United States.
See, we were told, you know, the way it was projected to us was different.
I think a lot of the reason that people felt the way they did, people that didn't demonstrate it felt
bad about Vietnam.
I don't think they understood about Vietnam.
And I know that's still a fact.
And like you said, they need to know.
There's so many people now, teenagers, whatnot, that have no idea, don't have a clue what went on.
A lot of them think, well, if you were stationed in Saigon, you never saw anything.
You just said differently, didn't you?
Oh, yeah, just like 716th MPs.
The Tet Offensive, Saigon was leveled.
You know, the Tet Offensive, American fighters strafed Saigon.
You know, I mean, blew it all to pieces.
They had to, but they blew it all to pieces.
Tonsnoot was right outside of Saigon.
I know personally because of guys that I left there that came to where I was...
That fought for 16 solid days.
You know, and right there.
It didn't matter where you were at there.
People don't understand that.
Lots of people, you know, don't understand that.
That there wasn't, and it's because of World War II and whatnot, that there wasn't a front, you know.
a place where you could fall back.
This is the front.
We'll go up there and then we'll fall back.
You're safe.
No place in Vietnam was safe is what you're saying.
No.
No place was safe.
Well, I think that the comments that you've made and the information that you have passed on going into the archives of Texas A&M University
We'll give the historians ammunition to, if you will use the word ammunition, to, because we're the ones that fight to get things put in history textbooks.
Right.
I understand that.
The United States, this is not the only thing the United States has liked to cover up.
They like to cover up a lot of the racism in the South.
Mm-hmm.
And lots of things they'd like to cover up, but historians keep bringing it out.
And I guess we're kind of a group of people that are kind of pioneers, just as people in space.
I'd like to think that we're doing our thing just as much as people in space towards getting an unknown that's right here on Earth.
across to the people.
I intend as a teacher to teach my students about the Vietnam War from all aspects of it because I believe that they should understand it.
Let me ask you one last question.
After some of the statements you made, I was wondering how you feel about
every young person, girl or boy, being required to spend at least two years in the service after they graduate from high school?
Do I think they should?
How do you feel about that?
Girl and boy?
I don't think a girl should be.
I think a guy should be.
Why not the girls?
The girls are asking for liberate, they want to be liberated.
Well, if they want to be, then let them.
I don't know.
I'm not saying send them into combat.
I'm just saying put them in the military to learn this discipline that you talked about.
I don't know that I'm in favor of the girls doing it.
Maybe that's just because I was raised that way.
I don't know.
But I think the draft ought to be back.
If not, I think a guy would be better off to go
Four years out of my life, I gave at the wrong time, I feel like.
I feel like I should have done it from the time I was 20 until I was 25, or almost 25.
I think those were important years in my life.
Well, that's why I said two years instead of four years.
Right, I agree.
Before that, it was two years.
Now, the Air Force, in order to volunteer in the other militaries, but the Army was only taking, you had to go four years, but the Army was doing two years.
I think two years is right, and I think that they should go right after they get out of high school.
And I think our military would be better.
I mean, it's proven fact.
There's no question about it.
that the military was better when the draft was there because you got everybody.
Some of those guys that was really good and really smart didn't go back to civilian jobs and make careers out of the military because they lacked it or something.
But now, you never get those guys to start with, so they never get exposed to any of it.
I think the discipline is important.
I think our...
Population needs the discipline.
I mean, I think maybe that's contributed to drugs somewhat, too.
I don't know.
But I think it should be, I think the draft, if nothing else, they should reinstitute the draft.
I think that threat, it was hanging over me.
There was jobs I couldn't get because I hadn't been drafted.
I hadn't been in the service.
They wouldn't even talk to me.
And I think that creates jobs.
for people.
I think there'd be a lot more employment, you know, available if ever a kid that come out of high school had the draft looking at him.
And he had to do that survey obligation before.
You know, most guys, when I came out of the high school, I didn't have a clue what I was going to do.
And most guys don't.
Most people don't.
No.
And that two years would be very valuable in deciding that, you know.
Yeah, I think it's important.
Well, I'd like to thank you, Ronnie, very much for your time.
This has been a time away from your family.
It's been my pleasure.
And I do appreciate it, and hopefully what you've said tonight, and I believe it will help the future, make the future safer for your children and your grandchildren.
Well, I hope so.
Thank you.
Thank you.
